media_caption: Leonor Orosa-Goquingco’s “Morolandia,” part of Filipinescas: Philippine Life, Legend and Lore in Dance, Paris, 1961
text_description: Leonor Orosa-Goquingco produces her significant work, Filipinescas: Philippine Life, Legend and Lore in Dance, which consolidates some of her earlier works as far back as 1938 such as Vinta and Morolandia.

media_caption: Alice Reyes, 2014
text_description: Alice Reyes’s concert is presented at CCP, leading to the CCP Summer Workshop and the establishment of the CCP Dance Company.

Activists affiliated with the Konsehong Tagapag-ugnay ng Rebolusyonaryong Sining present Pest of Badway in front of CCP. Directed by Behn Cervantes and Leo Rimando, it parodies Best of Broadway, which is showing at the CCP.

media_caption: Andres KKK, Philippine Ballet Theatre, CCP, Manila, 1996
text_description: These historical events from 1892 to 1896 will inspire the creative work of future dancers and choreographers such as Gener Caringal's Andres KKK.

media_caption: Monique Wilson dancing the One Billion Rising flash mob dance with some members of the Gabriela Women’s Party, Mendiola, Manila, 2014
text_description: The dance flash mob is utilized by the campaign One Billion Rising led by the women’s group Gabriela, OBR coordinator Monique Wilson, and feminist nun Sr. Mary John Mananzan. The successful campaign is repeated in succeeding years all over the country.

media_caption: Portrait of Praxedes Julia Fernandez aka Yeyeng, star of the Spanish zarzuela in the 1890s
text_description: Praxedes “Yeyeng” Fernandez dances a cancan number in a zarzuelita titled Pascual Bailon eliciting strong reactions, positive from the audience and negative from the church.
Dances are performed at the celebrations in Malolos Congress on Sep 15 and during the ratification on Sep 29 of the independence proclaimed at Kawit, Cavite on Jun 12.

media_caption: La Revolucion Filipina, Ballet Philippines, CCP, Manila, 2014
text_description: Quadrilles are performed in the Malolos convent, which served as Aguinaldo’s Palacio Presidencial, in the evening of Jan 23. The Malolos Republic and the conflicts within the leadership of the Philippine Revolution after the death of Bonifacio, such as the clash between Emilio Aguinaldo and Apolinario Mabini, will inspire Agnes Locin's La Revolucion Filipina.

media_caption: Street dance during the Kasaysayan ng Lahi parade, CCP, Manila, 1974
media_credit: (Kasaysayan ng Lahi: A History of the Filipino People. National Media Production Center, 1974)
text_description: The highlight of the inauguration of FAT is a spectacular street parade with streetdancing titled Kasaysayan ng Lahi.

media_caption: First significant batch of Filipino dancers, including Leonor Orosa-Goquingco and Rosalia Merino-Santos, taught by Luva Adameit during the American period
text_description: Polish choreographer Luva Adameit aka Madame Adameit (1895-48) establishes the Cosmopolitan Ballet and Dancing School in Manila. Her students include Leonor Orosa, Remedios de Oteyza, Rosalia Merino, Inday Gaston, Joji Felix, Chloe Cruz, Pacita Madrigal, and Fely Franquelli.

media_caption: Jota by the Bayanihan Philippine Dance Company, Expo ‘70 World Fair, Osaka, Japan
text_description: Bayanihan performs at Brussels Universal Exposition and wins over 13 national dance groups. The Ed Sullivan Show features the Bayanihan telecast with some 40 million television viewers.

media_caption: Tales of the Manuvu, CCP Dance Company, CCP, Manila, 1977
text_description: Tales of the Manuvu, a rock opera ballet in five parts based on indigenous myths and tales is staged by Alice Reyes at the CCP with script and libretto by Bienvenido Lumbera (1932- ) and music by Nonong Pedero and the Afterbirth.
Eddie Elejar receives the Gawad CCP para sa Sining.

media_caption: UP Peryante in a kilos-awit performance, Liwasang Bonifacio, Manila, 1983
text_description: UP Peryante and Patatag, composed of students and young cultural activists, popularize the kilos-awit, a street performance with singing and body movements. The creative protest action is performed in venues like the business district of Makati, Liwasang Bonifacio, and Mendiola Bridge.
Juan C. Miel publishes Samar Folk Dances.

media_caption: A contemporary dance performance by Seven Dance, 7th WiFi Body Festival, CCP, Manila
text_description: The first contemporary dance festival in the Philippines, the Wifi Body Festival, 2007-17, begins in CCP. Wifi will produce choreographers like Ava Villanueva, Rhosam Prudenciado Jr, Zyda Marie Baaya, Gerardo Francisco, Mia Cabalfin, Jed Amihan, Alfred Mercado, Frederick Fernandez, Ea Torrado, Al Bernard Garcia, Sarah Marie Samaniego, Japhet Mari Cabling, and Razielle Ann Mitchao.

media_caption: Alleluia Panis and Joey Maliga of Kulintang Arts Ensemble
text_description: In San Francisco, USA, Kulintang Arts, Inc. popularly known as Kularts, is established by Robert L. Henry, Marcella Pabros, and Alleluia Panis as its artistic director, to support the creation of works inspired by indigenous Philippine traditions.
Another zarzuela in 1887, El Hijo de Su Papa, features Patrocinio Tagaroma dancing cancan and tango numbers passionately received by the audience.

media_caption: Ati-Atihan in Kalibo, Aklan, 2014
text_description: In Kalibo, Aklan, the Ati-atihan, a precolonial tradition, is transformed into a Filipino version of the Mardi Gras with weeklong events and dancers dressed up in exaggerated or exotic costumes and fantastic makeup.

media_caption: The beheading of Longhino in the moriones of Boac, Marinduque, 1974
text_description: The same touristic transformation happens with the Moriones Festival in Boac, Marinduque.
Teresita Pascua-Ines publishes Ilocano Folk Dances.

Alay sa Pangulo, a show to celebrate the birthday of Ferdinand Marcos at the CCP, has Rudolf Nureyev and Margot Fonteyn as guest performers. Marcos confers the International Artist Award on Fonteyn and Van Cliburn.

media_caption: Greg Sta. Ines, left, and Jonathan Romulo in PETA’s May-I, May-I, Dulaang Rajah Sulayman, Manila, 1979
text_description: The Philippine Educational Theater Association presents the full-length May-i, May-i with choreography by Ligaya Amilbangsa about ancient Manila under the reign of Muslim leader Raha Sulayman from a scenario by Emman Lacaba, at Fort Santiago.

media_caption: Macli-ing Dulag, Kalinga chieftain killed for leading the protest against the construction of dams.
media_credit: (Photo by Lin Neumann in Macli-ing Dulag: Kalinga Chief Defender of the Cordillera by Ma. Ceres P. Doyo.  University of the Philippines Press, 2015.)
text_description: Macli-ing Dulag's death occasions massive protests. It will be commemorated as Cordillera day in the succeeding years, celebrated with Cordillera dances.

media_caption: Discorama, ca 1970
media_credit: (GMA Gold: Fifty Years of Broadcast History. GMA Network Inc, 2001)
text_description: Disco dancing becomes a craze and disco clubs proliferate in Metro Manila and other key cities of the country. Disco dancing also dominates television variety shows.

media_caption: A couple dancing the binanog, Iloilo City, 2016
text_description: The Historia de las Islas e Indios de Bisayas by Jesuit missionary Francisco Ignacio de Alcina describes Visayan dances such as a courtship dance imitating the mating of birds like the binanog.

media_caption: Trudl Dubsky-Zipper’s La Muerte de Ase, 1939
text_description: Viennese dancer-teacher-choreographer Trudl Dubsky (1913-1976) teaches modern dance at the Academy of Music and foreign dances at the University of the Philippines. Under the auspices of the Asociacion Musical de Filipinas, she forms Manila Ballet Moderne with productions like Petite Suite—Au Bord de la Seine (Little Suite—of the Seine) to Debussy, The Iron Foundry to Mossolow, Peer Gynt Suite to Grieg, and Voices of Spring to Strauss.

media_caption: Dinuy-a, an Ifugao ceremonial dance, 2013
text_description: Ritual dancing with animal sacrifice called cañao and spontaneous group dancing such as dinuyya are primeval dances of the Ifugao.

media_caption: A version of the escotis, Bayanihan Philippine Dance Company, Manila, ca 1970
text_description: Maestro Appiani, an Italian choreographer and dance teacher, forms the Compañia Infantil de Baile to perform in theaters like the Teatro de Binondo. For over a decade, he teaches ballroom dancing routines, among them quadrilles like the gavotte and rigodon, the redova, and the schottische.

media_caption: Sakuting by the Philippine Baranggay Folk Dance Troupe
text_description: The Philippine Normal College Baranggay Folk Dance Troupe organized by Paz Cielo A. Belmonte (1916-2013) performs at the first Philippine Floating Exposition in Southeast Asian countries.

media_caption: Diyandi Festival, Iligan City, 2009
text_description: In Iligan, Mayor Camilo Cabili appoints Felicidad Actub, head of Katilingbanong Kapunungang Iliganon, to organize a diyandi dance group from the traditional culture bearers who perform the religious ritual in honor of San Miguel every 29th of September. The religious feast will be transformed into a festival with street dancing in 2004.

media_caption: Hip-hop group Philippine All Stars performing different hip-hop movements, Manila, 2008
media_credit: (Niccolo Cosme, photo courtesy of Philippine All Stars)
text_description: Hip-hop dancing captivates the youth and MTV Asia produces a music video featuring the elements of hip-hop.

media_caption: Dancers doing a Latin American number in a bodabil performance, ca 1960
text_description: Groups in the international vaudeville circuit perform in the Philippines, like the Lilliputians in 1901 with their “ballet girls.”
Teatro Zorrilla presents Novelty in Manila, an American production featuring various acts like comedy skits, acrobatics, contortionists’ display, singing and dancing.

media_caption: Tony Fabella’s Limang Dipa, modern ballet by Dance Theater Philippines, Pasig City, 1981
text_description: Limang Dipa, a choreography by Tony Fabella (1941-2009) in modern ballet and jazz with original Filipino compositions, is premiered by Dance Theater Philippines at the Meralco Theater with dancers Anna Villadolid (1964- ) and Lisa Macuja (1964- ).

media_caption: Ligaya Fernando Amilbangsa performing her choreography of langka budjang (female martial dance) using a fan, Seoul, Korea, 1988
text_description: The Tausug and Sama perform the langka dances, which resemble the ancient martial arts in Indonesia. Both are based on mastery of the self and alignment with the spiritual dimension.

media_caption: Igorot men performing at the St Louis World’s Fair, USA, 1904
text_description: Performances at the St. Louis Exposition include the sarsuwela Walang Sugat, the repertory of the Philippine Constabulary Band, and ethnic performances such as Igorot dances with gongs, along with reenactments of head hunting and dog-eating rituals.

media_caption: Langka baluang by Abdurmihan Ladja of the Tambuli Cultural Troupe, 1976
text_description: Ligaya F. Amilbangsa premieres Paglami-lami (Celebration) at the CCP, dedicated to Orosa-Goquingco who was born in Sulu. The full show features the Tambuli Cultural Troupe of MSU Tawi-Tawi. The dance group aims to preserve the cultural expressions and dance traditions of the Sama, Badjao, Tausug, and Jama Mapun at the height of the military campaign against Moro separatist groups.

media_caption: Rigodon de honor at Malacañan with Commonwealth President Manuel L. Quezon and guests, 1938
text_description: The rigodon de honor is performed in Malacañan with the new national officials.

media_caption: Sinulog Festival, Cebu City, 2015
media_credit: (Teddy Uy, courtesy of Sinulog Foundation Inc.)
text_description: After the successful colonization of the Cebuano, sinulog is transformed into a dance to venerate the Santo Niño housed in the first church built by the Spaniards.

media_caption: Subli, as performed in Batangas, 1991
text_description: In celebration of Batangas City Foundation Day, the Cultural Affairs Board of Batangas City launches the annual Sublian Festival to encourage school and community groups to learn the dances, songs, and prayers from the traditional manunubli and to perform 10-minute excerpts in the annual competition.

media_caption: Dance number from Dance Time with Chito, ca 1970
media_credit: (GMA Gold: Fifty Years of Broadcast History. GMA Network Inc, 2001)
text_description: Channel 7 airs Dancetime with Chito. The hit TV show pioneers in TV dancing, featuring Chito Feliciano and his group performing ballroom dances, such as chacha, rhumba, and tango.

media_caption: Panagbenga Festival, Baguio City, 2016
text_description: The Baguio Flower Festival, also known as the Panagbenga (season of blossoming) begins as an annual festival to highlight Baguio’s flower industry and Cordillera culture, with advocacies such as respect for and protection of the environment. Indigenous performances such as male gangsa-playing and female banga or pot dance are part of the festival.

media_caption: Fulgencio Tolentino and Severino Reyes’s Walang Sugat, Tanghalang Pilipino, CCP, Manila, 2012
text_description: Walang Sugat by Severino Reyes (1861-1942) is premiered at the Teatro Libertad. The sarsuwela features dances such as balitaw and balse which are dances derived from Hispanic forms.
Foreign vaudeville groups continue to perform locally such as the Japanese Infantile company with its “Japanese ballet” and the Baroufski Imperial Russian Circus in 1902.

media_caption: Francisca Reyes-Aquino, seated second from right, with other Ramon Magsaysay awardees, 1962
text_description: Francisca Reyes-Aquino receives the Ramon Magsaysay Award for government service as “teacher and researcher of traditional performing arts who facilitated a creative national expression of Filipino culture.”

media_caption: Francisca Reyes-Aquino, National Artist for Dance, 1972
text_description: Francisca Reyes-Aquino is proclaimed first National Artist for Dance.

media_caption: Leonor Orosa-Goquingco, National Artist for Dance, 1972
text_description: · Leonor Orosa-Goquingco is proclaimed as National Artist for Dance.

media_caption: Alice Reyes, National Artist for Dance, 2014
text_description: Alice Reyes is proclaimed National Artist for Dance but conferment happens two years after.

media_caption: Kalinga suite by the Ramon Obusan Folkloric Group, Ugat Ugnayan, CCP, Manila, 2013
text_description: PBT and Ramon Obusan Folkloric Group become resident companies of the CCP, receiving some funding and a performance venue grant at the Tanghalang Nicanor Abelardo. Ballet Philippines and Bayanihan continue as CCP resident companies.

media_caption: Sayaw sa Bangko by Philippine High School for the Arts’s Sanghiyas Pangkat Mananayaw, Pindayog, Rizal Park, Manila, 2017
text_description: The Philippine High School for the Arts, atop Mt Makiling in Laguna, opens offering scholarships in dance and the other arts.

media_caption: A Midsummer Night’s Dream, Ballet Philippines, CCP, Manila, 1989
text_description: Trudl Dubsky-Zipper choreographs and designs A Midsummer Night’s Dream which premieres at the Rizal Memorial Coliseum. It combines classical ballet and modern dance and uses Philippine jusi and scenic projection in costumes and set design. Its dancers come from the foremost ballet schools in Manila: Remedios de Oteyza’s Classical Ballet Academy, Anita Kane’s School of the Classic Dance, Pacita Madrigal-Warns’ Manila Ballet Academy.

media_caption: Lucrecia Reyes-Urtula, National Artist for Dance, 1988
text_description: Lucrecia Reyes-Urtula is proclaimed National Artist for Dance.

media_caption: Dancing in One Voice, Philippine Ballet Theatre, CCP, Manila, 2015
text_description: After the Feb EDSA Revolt, the Philippine Ballet Theatre (PBT) is established as a CCP resident company in response to an appeal to CCP to support ballet artists outside of Ballet Philippines. PBT is formed by six dance groups / dance schools represented by Leonor Orosa-Goquingco, Inday Gaston-Mañosa, Julie Borromeo, Sony Lopez, Tita Radaic, Gener Caringal, and Tony Fabella.

media_caption: Pangalay: Traditional Dances and Related Folk Artistic Expressions, publication on dance research by Ligaya Fernando Amilbangsa, 1983
media_credit: (Photo of book cover courtesy of Ligaya Fernando Amilbangsa and Filipinas Foundation for the Ministry of Muslim Affairs)
text_description: Ligaya F. Amilbangsa’s Pangalay: Traditional Dances and Related Folk Artistic Expressions is published.

media_caption: Andres KKK, Philippine Ballet Theatre, CCP, Manila, 1996
text_description: Andres KKK, choreographed by Gener Caringal (1947- ) for PBT, celebrates the centennial of the 1896 revolution about the heroism and fall of Andres Bonifacio.

media_caption: Bayani Casimiro, tap dancing in Gerardo de Leon’s So Long, America, 1946
text_description: The inauguration is greeted by a floor-show with Carmen “Miami” Salvador, the Philippines’ Fred Astaire Bayani Casimiro, and the Diaz Sisters at the Santa Ana Cabaret; and high society balls of the Club Filipino, Kahirup, and Mancomunidad Pampangueña ballroom dances.

media_caption: Philippine National Dances, Francisca Reyes-Tolentino's anthology of indigenous and folk dances documented from all over the archipelago
text_description: · UP President Bocobo commissions Francisca Reyes-Tolentino, Antonino Bunevantura, and Ramon Tolentino to document folk dances, songs, music, music instruments, and other related artistic and cultural expressions.

media_caption: Philippine Dance: Mainstream and Crosscurrents by Reynaldo G. Alejandro. Vera-Reyes, 1978
media_credit: (Photo of book cover courtesy of Reynaldo G. Alejandro and Vera-Reyes, Inc)
text_description: Philippine Dance: Mainstream and Crosscurrents by Reynaldo G. Alejandro (1944-2009) is published.

media_caption: Crisostomo Ibarra, Ballet Philippines, CCP, Manila, 2010
text_description: The novel will later inspire works by future generations of dancers and choreographers: Leonor Orosa-Goquingco's Noli Dance Suite, Cora Iñigo's Sisa, Agnes Locsin's Elias, and Paul Alexander Morales's Crisostomo Ibarra

media_caption: Diablos, PETA, Dulaang Rajah Sulayman, 1989
text_description: Diablos (Demons), an experimental dance drama based on a Bagobo folktale is choreographed by Denisa Reyes, and is premiered by PETA and CCP at Dulaang Raha Sulayman, Fort Santiago, Manila. The story is about a woman about to give birth in a town suffering the ravages of war.

media_caption: For the Gods, Ballet Philippines, CCP, Manila, 1985
text_description: For the Gods, a modern dance in one act inspired by the Bukidnon thanksgiving ritual dugso, is choreographed by Denisa Reyes for Ballet Philippines at the CCP.

media_caption: Indios Bravos, Airdance, Quezon City, 2004
text_description: Airdance Theatre Inc is founded by dancers from Powerdance. Productions include Indios Bravos, 2004, Love Potion No. 9, 2007, and Adarna, 2011.

media_caption: Juru-Pakal, CCP Dance Workshop Company, CCP, Manila, 1971
media_credit: (Manila Chronicle Photo Collection, courtesy of Lopez Museum)
text_description: Juru-Pakal (The Enchanted Kris), a modern ballet in one act based on a Mindanao epic is choreographed by Eddie Elejar (1934- ) and is performed by the CCP Dance Workshop Company, later Ballet Philippines, at the CCP. It uses Asian theater traditions Kabuki drama and dance movements from Thailand, Indonesia, and Cambodia.

media_caption: Kayaw, Larawan Dancing Group, CCP, Manila, 1974
text_description: Ramon Obusan (1938-2006) premieres Kayaw (Headhunt) at the CCP. The performance features the Larawan Dancing Group with indigenous Kalinga performers. Obusan is the founder of the Ramon Obusan Folkloric Group. organized to preserve and develop traditional Philippine music and dance

media_caption: La Lampara, CCP Dance Company, CCP, Manila, 1980
text_description: The novel El Filibusterismo will fire up the imagination of future choreographers, as in Basilio's La Lampara and Morales’s Simoun.

media_caption: La Revolucion Filipina, Ballet Philippines, CCP, Manila, 2014
text_description: For the same commemoration, La Revolucion Filipina (The Philippine Revolution) is choreographed by Agnes Locsin for Ballet Philippines, narrating the conflicts between Mabini and Aguinaldo during the period of the Malolos Republic.

media_caption: Anita Kane’s Mariang Makiling, Ateneo de Manila Auditorium, Manila, 1939
text_description: Teacher-choreographer Anita Kane (1910 - n.d.) produces the first full-length ballet Mariang Makiling to original music by Ramon Tapales with Elisa Robles in the title role. It is the first to use a local legend and a composition originally created for ballet.

media_caption: Mir-i-nisa, Dance Theater Philippines, CCP, Manila, 1969
media_credit: (Philippine Dance: Mainstream and Crosscurrents by Reynaldo G. Alejandro. Vera-Reyes Inc, 1978)
text_description: Mir-i-nisa is the first Filipino ballet presented during the inaugural season of the CCP, choreographed by Julie Borromeo and Felicitas Layag-Radaic (1936- ), based on a short story by Jose Garcia Villa.

media_caption: Misa Filipina, Philippine Ballet Theatre, CCP, Manila, 2008
text_description: To dramatize the assassination of Ninoy Aquino Jr in 1983, Misa Filipina (Filipino Mass), a ballet for Holy Mass, is choreographed and designed by Basilio aka Basilio Esteban Villaruz (1940- ) at the Manila Cathedral and at Puerta Real, Intramuros, Manila, with dancers from Dance Theater Philippines.

media_caption: “Asalto for Maria,” part of Noli Dance Suite, CCP, Manila, 2011
text_description: The Noli Dance Suite, a modern ballet in one act by Leonor Orosa-Goquingco inspired by the writing of Jose Rizal, premieres at the GSP Auditorium.

media_caption: Of Cocks and Kings, Ballet Philippines, CCP Manila, 1979
text_description: Of Cocks and Kings, a dance drama in one act by Rosalia Merino-Santos (1923-) based on a short story by Alejandro R. Roces (1924-2011) with music by Lucrecia R. Kasilag, is performed by the FEU Modern Experimental Dance Workshop at the Far Eastern University Auditorium.

media_caption: One Ton Pinay, New York City, USA, 1979
text_description: In New York, Denisa Reyes (1952- ) premieres One Ton Pinay, a solo dance in three parts presented in the concert titled Neo-Filipino. The name “Neo-Filipino” eventually becomes the title of a choreographic series under Reyes’s direction showcasing experimental works of new choreographers.

media_caption: Rama, Hari, Ballet Philippines, CCP, Manila, 2012
text_description: Rama, Hari premieres at CCP, a rock opera ballet based on the Ramayana choreographed by Alice Reyes, with music by Ryan Cayabyab, libretto by Bienvenido Lumbera and English translation by Rolando S. Tinio, set and costume design by Salvador Bernal, lighting design by Katsch Catoy; with Nonoy Froilan / Robert Medina, and Basil Valdez (Rama); Ester Rimpos / Effie Nañas, and Kuh Ledesma (Sita); Edna Vida and Gigi Escalante (Soorpanakha).

media_caption: Sisa, Ballet Philippines, CCP, Manila, 1978
text_description: Sisa, a modern dance in one act is choreographed by Cora Generoso-Iñigo (1930- ) based on a play by Amelia Lapeña-Bonifacio (1930- ), performed by the UP Filipiniana Dance Group at UP Diliman.

media_caption: Star Maiden, Dance Forum Studio, Quezon City, 1997
media_credit: (Norman Jaravata, photo courtesy of Myra Beltran Collection)
text_description: Dance Forum, founded in 1995 by Myra Beltran (1960- ), opens its studio-theatre in Quezon City which becomes a venue for dancers and new choreographers. Works from 1997-2000 include Fragile Circle, Quartet for the End of Time, and Bachianas Brasilieras no. 1.

media_caption: Tagbanwa ritual, Cabayugan, Puerto Princesa, Palawan
media_credit: (Palaspas: An Appreciation of Palm Leaf Art in the Philippines by Elmer Nocheseda. Ateneo de Manila University Press, 2009)
text_description: The Palawan and Tagbanwa—the indigenous groups of Palawan Island, perform primordial dances such as the tarak/tarek and the pagdiwata ritual.
European performing groups continue to perform zarzuelas, operettas, operas, and can-can in local venues.

media_caption: Sama women performing the igal or pangalay, Busbus, Jolo, 1976
text_description: Pangalay/igal, a pre-Islamic and pre-Christian dance form similar to dance traditions in Cambodia, Indonesia, and other Asian countries, is performed by natives of the Sulu Archipelago.

media_caption: Alice Reyes’s Amada, CCP, Manila, 1978
text_description: The Alice Reyes and Modern Dance Company performs Amada at CCP.

media_caption: Alice Reyes’s Itim Asu, Alice Reyes and Modern Dance Company, Manila, 1970
text_description: Itim Asu (Onyx Wolf) is choreographed by Alice Reyes based on Virginia Moreno’s play The Onyx Wolf also at the CCP.

media_caption: Pangalay ha patong performed by members of the Ingat Kapandayan Artist Center of Notre Dame of Jolo College, 2013
text_description: Natives of the Sulu Archipelago perform pangalay postures and gestures, especially of arms and hands, which are similar to those inscribed on the walls of Angkor Wat.

media_caption: Sama Dilaut in a graveyard, Sulu Archipelago, ca 1983
text_description: During full moon, the Sama Dilaut perform rituals with dancing called magjinn aka igal jinn to appease malevolent or angered spirits.
Another song-dance form from Cuba called bolero spreads to the Hispanic world.

media_caption: Habanera de Jovencita by the Bayanihan Philippine Dance Company, ca 1970
text_description: Habanera, 19th century song dance from Havana Cuba, spreads to Hispanic countries.
An engraving by Nicolas de la Cruz Bagay from Velarde’s map illustrates the kumintang, a music and dance style indigenous to the areas presently known as Batangas.
The short period introduces a dance called ba-Ingles, from the words “baile” and “Ingles” or English dance.

media_caption: The cakewalk scene, Filipinas para los Filipinos, Manila, 1905
text_description: Severino Reyes’s Filipinas para los Filipinos features the cakewalk among other dances brought in during the early years of American colonization.
The Cebuano have been performing the sinulog even before the coming of the Spaniards.

media_caption: A bodabil chorus number, Manila Grand Opera House, ca 1950
text_description: The bodabil expands to include the “drama-skit” and is renamed stage show. Joe Climaco stages one of the first shows at the Life theater. Lou Salvador mounts shows at Dalisay, Strand and Palace theaters; Sammy Rodriguez and Lamberto Avellana at the Avenue; Ruben and Corazon Roque at the Lyric; Jose Generoso, the State; and Fernando Poe, the Capitol theater. These theaters are in Quiapo, Santa Cruz, and Avenida Rizal.

Western dances are performed at the grand balls of the 1908 carnival and subsequent carnivals. UP as leading state university will produce many of the country’s foremost dance groups, researchers, choreographers, dancers, and scholars.

media_caption: Sagayan, FEU Dance Troupe, ca 1990
text_description: Relatedly, the Maguindanaw and the Maranaw prepare for battle through a sacred war dance, the sagayan, inspired by the epic hero Bantugan.
Ballroom dancing such as waltz, fox-trot, quickstep, and swing are performed at the Santa Ana Cabaret and other similar establishments.

media_caption: Invitation for the sarsuwela Dalagang Bukid to be performed at the Teatro Zorrilla on Azcarraga,  now Claro M. Recto Avenue, in Manila, 1919
text_description: Dalagang Bukid (Country Maiden) premieres at the Teatro Zorrilla, Manila, with Honorata “Atang” de la Rama (1902-91) in the title role. As the most popular Tagalog sarsuwela of the era, Jose Nepomuceno produces it into the first full-length Filipino feature silent film in 1919, with Atang de la Rama in the title role. She sings and dances “Nabasag ang Banga” with a bakya for some film screenings in Manila.
Anna Pavlova, lead dancer of the Imperial Russian Ballet, graces the Manila Grand Opera House, enticing local girls to study ballet, among them Anita Kane.

The Kahirup organization composed of sugar barons holds lavish annual balls at the Manila Hotel, highlighted by a rigodon de honor with the participation of high society women dressed in elegant ternos.

media_caption: Tatlong Kuwento ni Lola Basyang, Ballet Manila, Aliw Theater, Manila, 2015
text_description: Ballet Manila presents Tatlong Kwento ni Lola Basyang with choreography by Osias Barroso, Lisa Macuja-Elizalde, and Tony Fabella.
Jose Honorato Lozano documents in water color the folk song-dance kundiman, popular from the beginning of the 1800s.

Cebuano jazz artist Luis Borromeo aka Borromeo Lou is back from America and opens the first bodabil company featuring jazz music and various acts with pop and theatrical dances from the US at the Olympic Stadium in Manila.

media_caption: 1924 Manila Carnival poster by Fernando Amorsolo
media_credit: (Copyright owned by Fernando C. Amorsolo Art Foundation, Inc; photo from Amorsolo: 1892-1972 by Alfredo Roces. Filipinas Foundation, Inc, 1975.)
text_description: Lou Borromeo’s bodabil production titled Borromeo’s Follies, featuring dancing girls, singers, musicians, comedians, and magicians, is launched at the Manila Carnival’s national fair at the Olympic Stadium.

media_caption: Francisca Reyes-Aquino, 1972
text_description: Francisca “Kikay” Reyes-Tolentino (1899-1983) publishes her research cowritten with Petrona Ramos titled Philippine Folk Dances and Games which is the first in a series of publications on Philippine folk dance.
Trudl Dubsky-Zipper and her husband, orchestra conductor Herbert Zipper, join the underground resistance.

Gironiere’s book describes the turumba in Pakil, Laguna in honor of the Nuestra Señora de los Dolores de Turumba. People who are sick and with disabilities join the throng of dancing devotees, hoping to be cured.
Jorge Bocobo becomes fifth UP President. His emphasis is on awareness of native culture for nation-building.
To revive and popularize Filipino songs and dances, Francisca Reyes-Tolentino establishes the University of the Philippines Folk Song and Dance Club.

media_caption: Leonor Orosa-Goquingco, 1972
text_description: Premiered at the Metropolitan Theater is Trend: Return to Native, a folkloric ballet in five parts choreographed by Leonor Orosa-Goquingco (1917-2005).
Manila Ballet Moderne premieres Pictures at an Exhibition at the Manila Metropolitan Theater with choreography and costumes by Trudl Dubsky-Zipper.

media_caption: Metropolitan Theater, ca 1930
media_credit: (Colorized by Bilog Bilugan, John Tewell Collection)
text_description: Japanese songs and dances are performed at the Metropolitan Theater.
The Japanese ban American films, and Filipino movie production. Film actors and directors work for the stage show.
Dubsky-Zipper continues to conduct dance classes on the rooftop of her apartment.
Bruna P. Seril establishes the Philippine Dance Company in New York, USA, performing folk dances researched by Francisca Reyes Aquino.

media_caption: Carmen Rosales and Rogelio dela Rosa in Maalala Mo Kaya, 1954
text_description: The stage show maintains its popularity. To celebrate the end of the Japanese occupation, Salvador stages a grand show at the Apollo for 40 days featuring big stars Carmen Rosales and Rogelio de la Rosa.

media_caption: Rosalia Merino-Santos in a modern dance performance, ca 1960
text_description: Dance scholars, choreographers, and educators are granted Fulbright scholarships: Francisca Reyes-Aquino, Rosalia Merino-Santos, Paz Cielo Belmonte, among others.

media_caption: Nestor de Villa and Nida Blanca in F. H. Constantino’s My Serenade, 1961
text_description: Films with music and dances, mostly pop and folkloric choreographies, are popular in the 1950s, featuring dancing stars like Pancho Magalona, Tita Duran, Dolphy, Bayani Casimiro, Nida Blanca, Nestor de Villa. Examples are Sa Isang Sulyap mo Tita, 1952; Waray-waray, 1954; Pilipino Kostum No Touch and Ikaw Kasi, 1955; Kalyehera, 1956; Tawag ng Tanghalan, 1958. This film genre extends to the 1960s with films like My Serenade, 1961, and Dance-o-Rama, 1962.
Anita Kane, kept as a virtual prisoner at the internment camp in the University of Santo Tomas in Manila for years, is released with other “internees.”
Dubsky-Zipper's Manila Ballet Moderne presents dance concerts for the troops of the United States Armed Forces in the Far East (USAFFE) at the undamaged Rex Theater.

Francisca Reyes-Aquino establishes the Philippine Folk Dance Society (PFDS) along with former members of the University of the Philippines Folk Song and Dance Club and the Bureau of Education Folk Dance Club, with the objective of preserving and promoting the traditional characteristics of Philippine folk dances.

media_caption: Francisca Reyes-Aquino, 1972
text_description: Francisca Reyes-Aquino publishes the first of her six-volume Philippine Folk Dances which will be used in the physical education classes all over the country.

media_caption: Lucrecia Reyes-Urtula’s Singkil by the Bayanihan Philippine Dance Company, ca 1970
text_description: Singkil, a folk dance choreography by Lucrecia Reyes-Urtula (1929-99), and music by Lucrecia R. Kasilag (1918-2008), is premiered by Bayanihan Philippine Dance Company in 1957 in Manila with lead dancer Henrietta Hofer as Princess.

Julie Borromeo (1941- ) arrives from the US after training with Luigi and Matt Matox, opens the first school to formally teach jazz dance, along with her sister, Rose Borromeo. Julie also established the Julie Borromeo Dance Company, the first formal jazz company in the Philippines.

media_caption: Leyte Kalipayan Dance Company
text_description: The Leyte Kalipayan Dance Company (LKCD) with Teresita Veloso-Pil as artistic director performs all over the country.
Easier travel route of Spain-Philippines-Spain facilitates the entry of artists and performers from Europe, resulting in the further spread of European social dances in the Philippines.

media_caption: Jota by the Bayanihan Philippine Dance Company, Expo ‘70 World Fair, Osaka, Japan
text_description: Bayanihan performs at Brussels Universal Exposition and wins over 13 national dance groups. The Ed Sullivan Show features the Bayanihan telecast with some 40 million television viewers.

text_headline: MALOLOS CONGRESS
text_description: Dances are performed at the celebrations in Malolos Congress on Sep 15 and during the ratification on Sep 29 of the independence proclaimed at Kawit, Cavite on Jun 12

text_headline: NOVELTY IN MANILA
text_description: Teatro Zorrilla presents Novelty in Manila, an American production featuring various acts like comedy skits, acrobatics, contortionists display, singing and dancing.

text_headline: JURU-PAKAL
text_description: Juru-Pakal (The Enchanted Kris), a modern ballet in one act based on a Mindanao epic is choreographed by Eddie Elejar (1934- ) and is performed by the CCP Dance Workshop Company, later Ballet Philippines, at the CCP. It uses Asian theater traditions Kabuki drama and dance movements from Thailand, Indonesia, and Cambodia.

text_headline: KASAYSAYAN NG LAHI
text_description: The highlight of the inauguration of Folk Arts Theater is a spectacular street parade with streetdancing titled Kasaysayan ng Lahi.

text_headline: FOR THE GODS
text_description: For the Gods, a modern dance in one act inspired by the Bukidnon thanksgiving ritual dugso, is choreographed by Denisa Reyes for Ballet Philippines at the CCP.

text_headline: VILMA IN PERSON
text_description: In television, Vilma Santos continues her variety show that showcases spectacular dance numbers in Vilma in Person (1986-95) over GMA Channel 7.

text_headline: The short period introduces a dance called ba-Ingles, from the words “baile” and “Ingles” or English dance.
text_description: The short period introduces a dance called ba-Ingles, from the words “baile” and “Ingles” or English dance.

text_headline: Maestro Appiani, an Italian choreographer and dance teacher, forms the Compañia Infantil de Baile to perform in theaters like the Teatro de Binondo.
text_description: Maestro Appiani, an Italian choreographer and dance teacher, forms the Compañia Infantil de Baile to perform in theaters like the Teatro de Binondo. For over a decade, he teaches ballroom dancing routines, among them quadrilles like the gavotte and rigodon, the redova, and the schottische.

text_headline: Jean Mallat (1846) writes about how deftly the Indios learn Spanish dances, such as the fandango, the zapateado, and the cachucha.
text_description: Jean Mallat (1846) writes about how deftly the Indios learn Spanish dances, such as the fandango, the zapateado, and the cachucha.

media_caption: Rigodon de honor at Malacañan with Commonwealth President Manuel L. Quezon and guests, 1938
media_credit: Foto News 1938, Eli Guieb III Collection
text_headline: English country dance (contredanse) becomes fashionable in French courts.
text_description: English country dance (contredanse) becomes fashionable in French courts; along with gavotte, and rigaudon, it spreads throughout Europe.

text_headline: During full moon, the Sama Dilaut perform rituals with dancing called magjinn aka igal jinn to appease malevolent or angered spirits.
text_description: During full moon, the Sama Dilaut perform rituals with dancing called magjinn aka igal jinn to appease malevolent or angered spirits.

text_headline: In Cebu, Antonio Pigafetta, Magellan’s chronicler, describes a dance ritual with swine sacrifice.
text_description: In Cebu, Antonio Pigafetta, Magellan’s chronicler, describes a dance ritual with swine sacrifice. Two old women don special garments and play reed trumpets while dancing around a pig with cloth and palm leaves, until one of them pierces the animal's heart.

text_headline: Ligaya Fernando Amilbangsa receives the Ramon Magsaysay Award.
text_description: Ligaya Fernando Amilbangsa receives the Ramon Magsaysay Award.

text_headline: Ballet Manila presents Tatlong Kwento ni Lola Basyang with choreography by Osias Barroso, Lisa Macuja-Elizalde, and Tony Fabella.
text_description: Ballet Manila presents Tatlong Kwento ni Lola Basyang with choreography by Osias Barroso, Lisa Macuja-Elizalde, and Tony Fabella.

text_headline: Denisa Reyes and Basilio Esteban Villaruz receive the Gawad CCP Para sa Sining.
text_description: Denisa Reyes and Basilio Esteban Villaruz receive the Gawad CCP Para sa Sining.

text_headline: The CCP launches the 1st CCP National Ballet Competition
text_description: The CCP launches the 1st CCP National Ballet Competition in Nov 2014 open to ballet dancers, choreographers, ballet masters, ballet school participants and their supporters from different parts of the country.

text_headline: The dance flash mob is utilized by the campaign One Billion Rising
text_description: The dance flash mob is utilized by the campaign One Billion Rising led by the women’s group Gabriela, OBR coordinator Monique Wilson, and feminist nun Sr Mary John Mananzan. The successful campaign is repeated in succeeding years all over the country.

text_headline: Agnes Locsin receives the Gawad CCP Para sa Sining.
text_description: Agnes Locsin receives the Gawad CCP Para sa Sining.

text_headline: The Cebuano have been performing the sinulog even before the coming of the Spaniards.
text_description: The Cebuano have been performing the sinulog even before the coming of the Spaniards. After the successful colonization of the Cebuano, sinulog is transformed into a dance to venerate the Santo Niño housed in the first church built by the Spaniards. Since 1980, sinulog has become a major dance festival with dance competitions.

text_headline: The Historia de las Islas e Indios de Bisayas by Jesuit missionary Francisco Ignacio de Alcina
text_description: The Historia de las Islas e Indios de Bisayas by Jesuit missionary Francisco Ignacio de Alcina describes Visayan dances such as a courtship dance imitating the mating of birds like the binanog.

text_headline: An engraving by Nicolas de la Cruz Bagay from Velarde’s map illustrates the kumintang
text_description: An engraving by Nicolas de la Cruz Bagay from Velarde’s map illustrates the kumintang, a music and dance style indigenous to the areas presently known as Batangas.

text_headline: Dance Pull's Karga Tapas (Cut and Load)
text_description: Dance Pull's Karga Tapas (Cut and Load), choreographed by Dwight Rodrigazo about the labors of the sacadas in Negros sugar plantations, is critically-acclaimed at the WiFi Body Independent Contemporary Dance Festival.

text_headline: Felicitas L. Radaic receives the Gawad CCP para sa Sining.
text_description: Felicitas L. Radaic receives the Gawad CCP para sa Sining.

text_headline: The first contemporary dance festival in the Philippines, the Wifi Body Festival, 2007-17, begins in CCP.
text_description: The first contemporary dance festival in the Philippines, the Wifi Body Festival, 2007-17, begins in CCP. Wifi will produce choreographers like Ava Villanueva, Rhosam Prudenciado Jr, Zyda Marie Baaya, Gerardo Francisco, Mia Cabalfin, Jed Amihan, Alfred Mercado, Frederick Fernandez, Ea Torrado, Al Bernard Garcia, Sarah Marie Samaniego, Japhet Mari Cabling, and Razielle Ann Mitchao.

media_caption: Joey de Leon, foreground right, with the Hotdog band in Discorama
text_description: Disco dancing becomes a craze and disco clubs proliferate in Metro Manila and other key cities of the country. Disco dancing also dominates television variety shows.

media_caption: UP Pep Squad’s cheerdance number, Pasinaya, CCP, Manila, 2017
text_description: UST Salinggawi wins the UAAP Cheerdance Competition for five consecutive years since 2002. They will be defeated the following year by UP PEP Squad, its closest rival.

Dario de Cespedes and his group stage the full-length Spanish zarzuela Jugar con Fuego (Playing with Fire), the first zarzuela performed in the Philippines, written by Ventura de la Vega, with music by Francisco Asenjo Barbieri of the Sociedad Artística del Teatro-Circo.

At the Manila Grand Opera House, the first jazz dance group, Shirley & the Moderners, is formed by Al Quinn (1933- ) with Jamin Alcoriza, Jack Jacinto, Arturo Zamora, Rally Calvo, Chito Feliciano, Shirley Santos, and Marie Cui.

Art Association of Bacolod initiates the MassKara Festival, a street dance of smiling masks and colorful costumes, to cheer up the people of Negros Occidental who are suffering due to the fall of the sugar industry and the death of their relatives in the sunken MV Don Juan. This is the start of the annual festival.

media_caption: Sinulog Festival, 2011
text_description: In Cebu, the sinulog is transformed into a festival with grand parades as conceived by a regional official of the office of youth and sports.

media_caption: PETA’s Nukleyar, Dulaang Rajah Sulayman, Manila, 1983
media_credit: (William B. Tan, PETA Library and Archives)
text_description: Issue-oriented plays with anti-dictatorship themes are produced by PETA, such as Nukleyar I and Oratoryo ng Bayan (The People's Oratorio), choreographed with eclectic body movements.

media_caption: Subli dancers
media_credit: (Photo by Neal Oshima, Subli: One Dance in Four Voices by Elena Rivera Mirano. Cultural Center of the Philippines, 1989.)
text_description: CCP launches Elena Rivera Mirano’s Subli: One Dance in Four Voices / (Subli: Isang Sayaw sa Apat na Tinig, which gives a multi-sided perspective on the traditional dance of Batangas.

media_caption: National Artist for Dance Alice Reyes, 2014
text_description: Alice Reyes receives the Gawad CCP para sa Sining.

media_caption: Dance adaptation of the Panay epic, Hinilawod, by Dagyaw Theater and Dance Company
media_credit: (Bayani ng Sayaw 1988 Dance Calendar and National Commission for Culture and the Arts)
text_description: The Dagyaw Theater and Dance Company of Iloilo High School performs Hinilawod at the First CCP National Theater Festival, choreographed by Locsin in collaboration with Edwin C. Duero.

media_caption: National Artist for Dance Ramon A. Obusan, 2006
text_description: Ramon Obusan receives the Gawad CCP Para sa Sining.

media_caption: Tud Bulul slashing a mountain with his kefilen or kris
text_description: In Mindanao, the Kahayag Community Dance and Theater Company performs its most acclaimed and popular work, Tudbulul, a narrative dance that interprets the Tboli’s great epic.

media_caption: Members of the Bayanihan Philippine Dance Company performing the polka, ca 1970
text_description: Bayanihan is declared the National Folk Dance Company of the Philippines.

media_caption: National Artist for Dance Ramon A. Obusan, 2006
text_description: CCP Centennial Honors for the Arts Award is given to Paz Cielo Belmonte, Cora Generoso-Iñigo, Libertad Fajardo, Carmen Locsin, Ramon Obusan, Alice Reyes, and Felicitas Radaic.

media_caption: 2000 Gawad sa Manlilikha ng Bayan (GAMABA) awardee Alonzo Saclag
text_description: Alonzo Saclag (1942- ), Kalinga musician and dancer who founded the Kalinga Budong Dance Troupe, is proclaimed as Gawad Manlilikha ng Bayan.

media_caption: National Artist for Dance Ramon A. Obusan, 2006
text_description: Ramon A. Obusan is proclained National Artist for Dance.

media_caption: Romeo and Juliet, Ballet Center Cebu, Cebu City, 2012
text_description: Cebu Ballet Center is renamed Ballet Center Cebu under Nicolas Pacaña and Gregory Aaron, in recognition of its founding by Fe Sala-Villarica in 1951. It is known for its classical ballet such as The Nutcracker and Swan Lake; and neo-classical ballets like Eclipse, Bella Amore and, Paganini.

media_caption: Karga Tapas, Dance Pull Company, CCP, Manila, 2008
text_description: Dance Pull's Karga Tapas (Cut and Load), choreographed by Dwight Rodrigazo about the labors of the sacadas in Negros sugar plantations, is critically-acclaimed at the WiFi Body Independent Contemporary Dance Festival.
Jovita Sison-Friese releases Philippine Folk Dances from Pangasinan.
The first Cordillera Day celebration is held in Sadanga, Mt Province with indigenous dances and music performed by the participating groups.
The first Makiisa Festival features anti-Marcos performances, exhibits, lectures, and workshops. It will be followed by a second one the next year.
Balletfest is launched with the participation of more than 20 dance companies and schools from all over the country.
Ballet Philippines represents the country in the 4th ASEAN Festival of Performing Arts hosted by the CCP.
To showcase folk dance groups from the whole archipelago, CCP launches the annual folk dance festival Pang-alay: A Festival of Philippine Folk Dances.
In television, Vilma Santos continues her variety show that showcases spectacular dance numbers in Vilma in Person (1986-95) over GMA Channel 7.
The first CCP National Dance Festival and Conference is launched in Iloilo with activities happening in other Visayan cities.
The CCP through its Outreach program, conducts folkdance workshops on the regional level with members of PFDS, particularly its board members acting as resource persons.
Paz Cielo Belmonte receives the Gawad CCP para sa Sining.
World Dance Alliance (WDA) is established on the occasion of the Hong Kong International Dance Conference in 1990 by Carl Wolz.

CCP launches the folk dance festival Sari-Saring Sayaw, Sama-Samang Galaw: Mga Tradisyon at Interpretasyon, held during the Philippine Arts Month in February. The festival brings together folk dance groups from all over the country.
Maniya Barredo (1951- ) receives the Gawad CCP para sa Sining.

The First Asian Dance Music Convention is held at the Philippine Convention Center with the participations of b-boys, hip-hop crews, and enthusiasts from all over the Philippines and around the globe.
The Association of Ballet Academies, Philippines (ABAP) is established to improve classical ballet education in the Philippines.
Rosalia Merino-Santos receives the Gawad CCP Para sa Sining.
CCP launches the CCP Encyclopedia of Philippine Art with one volume dedicated to dance.

In dance sport or competitive ballroom, the DanceSport Council of the Philippines, Inc holds its first dance congress at the Ninoy Aquino Stadium to introduce the competitive style of ballroom dancing. Two couples represent the Philippines in the international competition in Bangkok.
Cora Iñigo receives the Gawad CCP Para sa Sining.
The CCP and the NCCA, in cooperation with World Dance Alliance-Philippines, holds the Philippine International Dance Conference in Manila.

The PFDS launches the first book in the 8-volume series titled Sayaw: Dances of the Philippine Islands. Succeeding volumes will come out in 2000, 2001, 2002, 2003, 2005, 2010, 2014. Editors are Larry Gabao and Franco Velas.

Dayaw 2000, a traditional arts festival with indigenous dances from all over the Philippines, is held at the Rizal Park, organized by the CCP and NCCA. It is held in different provinces in the following years up to the 2010s.
Basilio Esteban Villaruz’s Treading Through 45 Years of Philippine Dance is published.
Felicitas L. Radaic receives the Gawad CCP para sa Sining.
Agnes Locsin receives the Gawad CCP Para sa Sining.

The CCP launches the 1st CCP National Ballet Competition in November 2014 open to ballet dancers, choreographers, ballet masters, ballet school participants and their supporters from different parts of the country.
Ligaya Fernando Amilbangsa receives the Ramon Magsaysay Award.
Denisa Reyes and Basilio Esteban Villaruz receive the Gawad CCP Para sa Sining.

media_caption: Jota caviteña by the Bayanihan Philippine Dance Company, ca 1970
media_credit: Philippine Dance: Mainstream and Crosscurrents by Reynaldo G. Alejandro. Vera-Reyes, 1978
text_headline: Fandango, a folk dance song in fast triple meter from Spain.
text_description: Fandango, a folk dance song in fast triple meter from Spain, is characterized by couple dancing and the use of castanets and guitar. Another Spanish folk song dance jota, which utilizes four octosyllabic lines, performed with castanets, guitar, and bandurrias, is disseminated throughout the 18th century.
